title: Ticket #4923: Cannot restart the collector on Windows, or shutdown takes a long time
description:
On Windows, the master is unable to restart the collector (or any daemon using a well-known port). Upon attempting to restart the collector, the MasterLog would contain errors like the following: 

  03/04/15 14:00:45 Collector port not defined, will use default: 9618
  03/04/15 14:00:45 Sock::bind failed: WSAError = 10048
  03/04/15 14:00:45 Failed to listen(9618) on TCP/IPv4 command socket. Does this computer have IPv4 support?
  03/04/15 14:00:45 Warning: Failed to create IPv4 command socket.
  03/04/15 14:00:45 ERROR: Create_Process failed trying to start C:\condor\bin\condor_collector.exe

The problem is the master is unable to restart the collector because port 9618 is already in use because when the master started the collector the first time, DaemonCore::Create_Process() posted a listen on 9618 and marked that listen socket as inheritable. It then starts a condor_procd if one is not already running (as of #2911). The result is the condor_procd inherited the 9618 listen socket, and thus that socket will stay in use until the procd is killed.

Besides failing to restart the collector, this bug also manifested itself when sometimes doing a net stop condor or "condor_master -master" on Windows would take a really long time. The reason was the master is waiting for all other daemons to exit, but if the collector shuts down first, other daemons may have to timeout waiting for the condor_procd to respond to collector commands sent to 9618. By fixing this bug, these timeouts will no longer occur, since now as soon as the collector shuts down clients will receive a connection refused error immediately.
